abstract.p: Letter from Craig A Landy, New York County Lawyers Assn president, scores Gov George E Pataki and New York Legislature for failing to raise pay rate for lawyers representing children and indigent adults (May 26 article)

block.p: The failure of Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Legislature to raise the pay rate for lawyers representing children and indigent adults is indeed regrettable (editorial, May 26). New York has the second-lowest compensation rate in the country, leading to a shortage of lawyers willing to accept cases.
In Family Court, up to 50 parents must be turned away each week. Criminal defendants wait years. Lawyers have inadequate time and resources to prepare cases.

The failure of Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Legislature to raise the pay rate for lawyers representing children and indigent adults is indeed regrettable (editorial, May 26). New York has the second-lowest compensation rate in the country, leading to a shortage of lawyers willing to accept cases.
In Family Court, up to 50 parents must be turned away each week. Criminal defendants wait years. Lawyers have inadequate time and resources to prepare cases.

In February, the New York County Lawyers' Association, of which I am president, sued Governor Pataki and the state to ensure that children and the indigent in family and criminal proceedings get the meaningful representation guaranteed by the federal and state Constitutions. Litigation, however, will not provide a prompt resolution. Responsible leadership by the governor and the Legislature is needed.
CRAIG A. LANDY New York, May 31, 2000
